messages.content:
Hey @shr1ftyy[τ,ℶ,κ] | SN26, SN10 

After looking at the subnet metrics, I believe that the incentive mechanism has some design flaws that miners are exploiting and could be exploited by validators.

I have identified two types of reward distortions:

- Latency distortion: for a miner A, you can find at least one miner B such that Miner A APY > Miner B APY and Miner A Latency > Miner B Latency -> Miner A Incentive < Miner B Incentive.
  - Broadly speaking, if your latency is low enough, as long as you are not affected by the penalty distortion, your APY doesn't really matter for your scoring and your incentive.

- Penalty distortion: for a miner A, you can find at least one miner B such that Miner A APY > Miner B APY and Miner A Latency < Miner B Latency and Miner A has penalty Miner B has not -> Miner A Incentive < Miner B Incentive. 
  - You can do better both in terms of APY and time. You can get a lower score than the worst miner because you have penalties.

Below is the current incentive landscape: miners APY against their latency, with their score as the circle size.

https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/eda36e18-02ff-46a6-a1f3-f3eb0a342998

https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/806989bf-4d87-40a2-8b36-1052457a7970

https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/97bbbf48-f441-4481-874b-07a89855523a

https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/cb1a473c-8f75-434e-8b7a-2f57f9b03690

What we should observe is the highest APY leading to the highest scores (largest circle area) but what we observe instead is the following:

- Most miner's scores are distorted (latency, penalties)  
- Miners among the lowest APY can end up with high scores because they are fast
- For multiple miner you can find other miner with lower APY or/and higher latency with higher scores (circle area)
- Miners that found a "niche" (minimize penalty) in the landscape can have both lower APY and higher latency and a high score 
  
With the current reward model, miners are currently encouraged to either:
 - Chase the lowest latency at the expense of APY   
 - Finding an APY latency combination that reduces penalty at the expense of APY, latency, or both
There is more details on solutions in the issue https://github.com/Sturdy-Subnet/sturdy-subnet/issues/63, but I am crossposting here for the discussion
By the way I do accept and welcome bounties 😂 :pushing_taowhite:  here is my wallet 5Hgbi3RgJvi9B1T8qYVciCt92cm9qAFKSfGiBof7adMB8FEY

We have analysed the miner data by fund flow of the coldkey on subnet 10, most of the miners are belongs A/B/C users.

We found when the validator of subnet 10 sends tasks to different miners, it requests according to the miners’ UIDs in ascending order. However, the recorded start time for each miner's request is the same. We have do lots of test and found:
1. requests to miners with larger UIDs are made later than those to miners with smaller UIDs. 
2. the time taken by miners with larger UIDs is less than that of miners with smaller UIDs. 

This seems somewhat unfair to the miners with small UIDs, as they cannot control this mechanism on their end.

I suggest that the validator shuffle the UIDs before calling query_and_score_miner: random.shuffle(active_uids).

### Weight changes detected for Subnet 10

a) There might be multiple subjects: 

1. What is the smallest delta in allocation that results in a change in APY, even small?
Here I 100% agree with you, the example I provided is not realistic, its goal was just to demonstrate with an extreme situation how the issue is manifesting in v1.*.  In practice small differences in allocation would results in small or no differences in the APY but even a 1e-16 difference in APY would be enough to rank miners.

If we get the APY sensitivity to allocation it would give us a better idea on the ratio between the APY and allocation thresholds.    

2. Does small or minute change in APY matters?
Here, I would say yes, the idea with setting the thresholds that low is to keep the order between miners before rescaling and to have a reward system that totally aligns miners with the product  however you want to expand it. If you keep the precision in all the computations you will be able to rescale the score without flattening the curve, if not you might loose the small differences between miners because of the loss of precision and get a flat curve.

This why I believe APY threshold should be ~1e-16, better APY even by a small margin is still better APY. 

3. What is the the goal of the similarity checking?
 If the goal  is to detect cheating (relay mining) the cheater will:  
-> send the same allocation as the honest miner, in this case they will get flag and penalized 
->  send the allocation with a delta if the delta is high enough to change the APY there is a chance that the allocation will have a lower APY or that the time computing a new allocation will result in a timeout.  In this case we need the allocation threshold to be high enough so that a change of this size delta change the APY even by one digit

  If the goal is to add diversity: 
-> I don’t think we should use penalties because if there is one allocation that is the best, we are penalizing miners for being close to it and rewarding miners that are far from it.

b) I believe it will work well, and in practice there a not as many miners as there are UIDs, the only concern I have is with torch precision. Using float32 even float64 will basically round the APYs before rescaling, it will create some stairs where miners with different APY get the same incentive even with rescaling. Running the calculation with gmpy2 would fix that issue, and if the exponent is high enough it would not be an issue to store the score in the tensor afterward.  

I can check for more realistic examples and check multiple pools sensitivity to better set the thresholds, I might get around it later this weekend or early next week!

```    apys = torch.tensor(list(raw_apys.values()), dtype=torch.float32)
```
once apy is greater than 3.4e+38 then above conversion results in `inf` then makes all rewards to nan or 0, nan is replaced to 0 and finally all rewards for allocations that includes apy greater than 3.4e+38 ends with 0.
current pr that replaced torch to numpy will be the same result
Not sure if this is on purpose, but some of my allocations results in 10e+250 apy

Here are some of my suggestions:
1. Rather than calcuating normalized apys by converting to torch.float32 or np.float32, better use python float calculation.
2. Make the apy annulalization formula more reasonable so that the reward will never exceed torch.float32 max value (3.4e+38)
Above is the example of that.
Another option maybe just handle exception when torch conversion and set it just 0 when it's inf, to prevent any `nan` results in rewards.
Most of the rewards are nan here.
these are comically high apys. ill look into this today. hope to have a fix out soon.

I believe what you are describing is relay mining . Some validators (you know yourselves) steal answers from miners , and then run miners and relay the answers

there are two viable fixes for relay mining already, but they are both situational

This is correct. In order to be able to set weights on a subnet (that is, to submit scoring for miners), validators need a minimum of 1000 alpha tokens staked (this is in a nutshell; of course it's more complicated than this).  In many cases, though, they'll still risk being deregistered, if they don't have enough stake with respect to the majority of the subnet and if they're not in consensus (their ranking is too out of step with the majority of the stakeholders).

To save your miner from doing work for a validator that's incapable of actually ranking it, most miners are coded to ignore requests from validators with insufficient stake.

That's what this error means: your miner has been queried by something claiming to be a validator that does not have enough stake to actually impact your miner's scoring, and so your miner is ignoring it.

The purpose of this subnet is yield optimization

Validators have to sort all miners according to their yields and then give rewards to them according to that rank

As the goal of this subnet, validators have to give rewards to miners according to yields they optimized.
Here, similarity and axon_time is important too but it cannot be important than the goal of this subnet.
